items.content_html:
My comment about no === in Swift was incorrect, thanks Matt!

I should know that a beginner course isn‚Äôt going to immediately explain referential equality, that won‚Äôt make sense yet.

https://mastodon.social/@mattiem/113203444245305184
items.content_text:
My comment about no `===` in Swift was incorrect, thanks Matt!

I should know that a beginner course isn‚Äôt going to immediately explain referential equality, that won‚Äôt make sense yet.

https://mastodon.social/@mattiem/113203444245305184

items.content_html:
No === in Swift (just ==) is nice!

Enums being comparable is pretty cool too.

And switch statements‚Ä¶ is this the day I confess that I tend not to use them in JavaScript? Swift‚Äôs fallthrough syntax seems much safer than JS needing a break for each case.

Day 5 done! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
No `===` in Swift (just `==`) is nice!

Enums being comparable is pretty cool too.

And `switch` statements‚Ä¶ is this the day I confess that I tend not to use them in JavaScript? Swift‚Äôs `fallthrough` syntax seems much safer than JS needing a `break` for each `case`.

Day 5 done! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
This is really interesting:

let name: String
// ‚Ä¶
name = "Chasen"
// Allowed once

In JavaScript, the ‚Äúequivalent‚Äù (using const) requires an initial value and doesn‚Äôt let you reassign it later. I like that Swift allows it be undefined and assigned just once.

Day 4 done! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
This is really interesting:

```swift
let name: String
// ‚Ä¶
name = "Chasen"
// Allowed once
```

In JavaScript, the ‚Äúequivalent‚Äù (using `const`) _requires_ an initial value and doesn‚Äôt let you reassign it later. I like that Swift allows it be undefined and assigned just once.

Day 4 done! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
Coming from JS, there are some small differences in array and dictionary syntax. This really stood out to me (as nice and explicit):

let olympics = [
    2016: "Rio de Janeiro",
    2021: "Tokyo",
    2024: "Paris"
]

print(olympics[2020, default: "Unknown"])

Day 3 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
Coming from JS, there are some small differences in array and dictionary syntax. This really stood out to me (as nice and explicit):

```swift
let olympics = [
    2016: "Rio de Janeiro",
    2021: "Tokyo",
    2024: "Paris"
]

print(olympics[2020, default: "Unknown"])
```

Day 3 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
This has a bug‚Ä¶ can you spot it?

let temperature = 29
let converted = (temperature * 9 / 5) + 32
print("Celsius: \(temperature)")
print("Fahrenheit: \(converted)")

I thought the compiler might warn when losing precision like this, but I guess not!

Day 2 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI
items.content_text:
This has a bug‚Ä¶ can you spot it?

```swift
let temperature = 29
let converted = (temperature * 9 / 5) + 32
print("Celsius: \(temperature)")
print("Fahrenheit: \(converted)")
```

I thought the compiler might warn when losing precision like this, but I guess not!

Day 2 in the books! #100DaysOfSwiftUI

items.content_html:
I‚Äôm going to compare Swift to JavaScript a lot as I get up to speed.

Seems like Swift‚Äôs var == let (in JS) and let == const. I‚Äôm sure that won‚Äôt trip me up‚Ä¶

Interesting that 1_00__00___00____00 is valid in Swift (JS only allows one separator per digit, not multiple).
items.content_text:
I‚Äôm going to compare Swift to JavaScript *a lot* as I get up to speed.

Seems like Swift‚Äôs var == let (in JS) and let == const. I‚Äôm sure that won‚Äôt trip me up‚Ä¶

Interesting that `1_00__00___00____00` is valid in Swift (JS only allows one separator per digit, not multiple).
